G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Complaint is brought under G.L. c. 208, § 28, which authorizes the court to modify a prior custody determination when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and such modification serves the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209B, \u00a7 2.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 209B, § 2, as both parents and the minor child reside within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The modification of custody is in the best interests of Sophia and aligns with the principles outlined in G.L. c. 208, § 31, and G.L. c. 209C, ensuring her physical, emotional, and developmental well-being.

G.L. c. 209C.proposition: The modification of custody is in the best interests of Sophia and aligns with the principles outlined in G.L. c. 208, § 31, and G.L. c. 209C, ensuring her physical, emotional, and developmental well-being.

See *Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608,.raw_text: See *Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 612 (1987).
See *Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608,.proposition: The Court has recognized the importance of giving weight to the reasonable preferences of older children in custody determinations.
See *Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608,.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss the child Tony’s expressed preference to live in Germany, but it explicitly states that the preference of a ten‑year‑old child is not given decisive weight, only that it is a factor to be considered. The court does not emphasize or elevate the "importance" of older children’s reasonable preferences; instead, it reaffirms that such preferences are one factor among many in a best‑interests analysis. Thus, the case does not support the proposition as stated.
See *Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608,.relevant_excerpt:
Tony’s custody presents a closer question. His father appears to have indoctrinated him with some dislike for his mother, and he has expressed a preference for Bielefeld. Furthermore, his familiarity with his father’s life in Bielefeld, something Rosemary lacks, might possibly make sending him to his father less traumatic. On balance, however, the judge’s decision, founded on a better knowledge of the parties than we can achieve from a cold record, is not plainly wrong.

The preference of someone Tony’s age (ten at the time of the proceedings) is not given decisive weight, although it is a factor to be considered.

See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 84.raw_text: See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 847 (2003); *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012).
See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 84.proposition: Case law consistently reinforces the principle that modifications may be warranted when the established custody arrangement no longer serves the best interests of the child. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 847 (2003); *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012).
See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 84.support_reasoning: This opinion is about an initial custody determination under the best‑interests standard and the statutory factors in G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a), not about modification of an existing custody judgment. The court explicitly declines to apply the ‘substantial change in circumstances’ standard from § 20 and does not discuss when a modification is warranted or how changes in circumstances affect an existing arrangement. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition that modifications may be warranted when an established custody arrangement no longer serves the child’s best interests.
See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 84.relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20….”}

See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 M.raw_text: See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 710-711 (1985); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404 (1981).
See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 M.proposition: Factors considered in determining the best interests of the child include the child’s need for stability, adjustment to home, and emotional well-being. See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 710-711 (1985); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404 (1981).
See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 M.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely frames the governing standard as the “best interests of the child” and then defines that in terms that include the child’s overall quality of life and the impact of the move on the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs. In describing the required evaluation, the court emphasizes the effect of removal on the child’s life, including quality of life and emotional needs, which encompasses stability, adjustment to home, and emotional well-being. Thus the case supports the stated proposition about relevant best-interest factors.
See *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 M.relevant_excerpt: “The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

See *Schaffer v. Schaffer*, 43 Mass. App.raw_text: See *Schaffer v. Schaffer*, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 743, 748 (1997).
See *Schaffer v. Schaffer*, 43 Mass. App.proposition: A party seeking modification must demonstrate that the current living situation is no longer in the child's best interests. See *Schaffer v. Schaffer*, 43 Mass. App. Ct. 743, 748 (1997).
See *Schaffer v. Schaffer*, 43 Mass. App.support_reasoning: This opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case about protective custody, blood draws, and evidentiary/sentencing issues. It does not involve family law, custody, or standards for modification of a child’s living situation, nor does it discuss the “best interests of the child” standard. Therefore it cannot support the proposition that a party seeking modification must demonstrate that the current living situation is no longer in the child's best interests.

See *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 81.raw_text: See *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 819 (1981).
See *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 81.proposition: The evidence demonstrates that the limited parenting time granted to Plaintiff in 2016 is no longer appropriate due to her improved circumstances and the evolving needs of the child. See *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 819 (1981).
See *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 81.support_reasoning: Hale v. Hale concerns whether a custodial parent may remove children from Massachusetts, and what factors constitute the children’s best interests in that relocation context. It does not involve modification of parenting time based on improved circumstances of a noncustodial parent or evolving needs of the child, nor does it discuss when previously limited parenting time becomes inappropriate. Using Hale as authority for modifying limited parenting time due to improved circumstances mischaracterizes the case’s holding and focus.
See *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 81.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests. More particularly, it does not appear that he considered the advantages of the move with respect to the emotional well-being of the family unit as a whole, or the emotional costs of forcing a stressful family and career choice… on the parent having the primary responsibility for the day-to-day care of the children.”

See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 1.raw_text: See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 186 (2006); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 261 (2001).
See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 1.proposition: Sophia's expressed desire to increase her time with Plaintiff also merits considerable weight as a child’s preferences are a valid factor in custody determinations. See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 186 (2006); *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 261 (2001).
See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 1.support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal / relocation case focusing on the best‑interests standard where parents share joint physical and legal custody. The opinion discusses factors such as school quality, disruption from relocation, the impact on each parent’s parenting time, and allegations involving a step‑sibling. It does not address, mention, or weigh the child’s stated custodial preferences as a factor, so it does not provide authority for the proposition that a child’s expressed desire to spend more time with a parent merits considerable weight in custody determinations.
See *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 1.relevant_excerpt: “The order is based on the judge’s findings that the children’s best interests would be negatively affected by this move. She made detailed written findings that their current schools were superior, that uprooting the children would be difficult for them, that the move would impair the father’s parenting to the detriment of their interests, that potential misconduct by other siblings in the mother’s household weighed against increased physical custody by the mother, and that any financial or other advantage of the move to the mother was unclear.”

See *Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619,.proposition: Courts must prioritize a parenting plan that maximizes the time and relationship with both parents when feasible. See *Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619, 621 (2000).
See *Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619,.support_reasoning: The opinion does not state or imply a general rule that courts must prioritize parenting plans that maximize time and relationships with both parents. The custody discussion is about this particular family's dynamics, the mother's problematic behavior, the children's special needs, and the procedural requirement that custody changes proceed by complaint for modification rather than motion. While the trial judge noted the father's appreciation of the importance of both parents, the Supreme Judicial Court does not adopt a broad presumption favoring maximum time with both parents.
See *Williams v. Massa*, 431 Mass. 619,.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found, based on credible evidence, that the husband ‘would more likely be able to make appropriate decisions to address the children’s special needs.’ On the other hand, the judge found that both children were deeply allied with their mother, and that she must continue in a significant way in their lives, ‘despite the worrisome behaviors she exhibits in her parenting.’ … A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28.”

See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590,.proposition: Defendant’s refusal to cooperate and inability to address Sophia’s emotional needs further highlights the importance of modification. See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 598 (1996).
See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590,.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a defendant’s refusal to cooperate and inability to address a child’s emotional needs as grounds highlighting the importance of modification. Custody of Vaughn addresses domestic violence, its impact on the child, and the need for explicit findings and reconsideration of a custody order; it does not discuss a parent’s refusal to cooperate with services or inability to meet emotional needs in the way described. The case is therefore not authority for the specific proposition cited.
See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590,.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’… The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother… Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.”
